title: A Randomized Controlled Trial on the Effectiveness of a Positive Psychology App for Adults in the General Population Dealing With Negatives Consequences of the Corona Crisis
description_brief: The corona crisis has a negative impact on the mental wellbeing of the Dutch population. Positive psychology exercises (PPOs) can potentially improve mental well-being and reduce mild and moderate psychological complaints. Previous research has shown moderate to large effects of PPOs on well-being in people with reduced wellbeing and psychological symptoms at baseline. The University of Twente developed an app (Training in Positivity; TiP) based on an effective intervention. The goal of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of TiP in the general population in people experiencing reduced mental wellbeing as a result of the corona crisis. People using the app will be compared to a waiting list control group.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is a positive-psychology smartphone app (Training in Positivity, TiP) developed by the University of Twente delivering exercises to improve mental well‑being in the general population affected by the coronavirus crisis; the study is an RCT versus a waiting-list control. This is a psychological/behavioral intervention, not a drug or biologic. citeturn0search0

Act: Key extracted details — intervention name: Training in Positivity (TiP) app; developer: University of Twente; mode: positive psychology exercises (themes: joy, self‑trust, future‑trust, kindness, resilience, connection); population: adults with reduced mental wellbeing due to the corona crisis; comparator: waiting-list control. No drug, biologic, or small‑molecule is involved. Supporting sources: University of Twente launch/description of the TiP app and related pilot/student studies. citeturn0search0turn0search4turn0search3

Reflect: The four target categories provided are specific to Alzheimer’s pharmacologic/neuromodulatory approaches (disease-targeted biologic, disease-targeted small molecule, cognitive enhancer, neuropsychiatric symptom improvement). Although the TiP app aims to improve mental well‑being and could reduce symptoms like mild depression/anxiety, it is a psychological/behavioral digital intervention rather than a pharmacologic or Alzheimer‑pathology‑targeting trial. Under the instructions to return 'N/A' when the trial does not fit the Alzheimer/drug-oriented categories, the correct classification is 'N/A'. If forced to map to one of the four categories by concept (not by instruction), the closest would be 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' because it targets mood/wellbeing, but per the task rules I return 'N/A'. citeturn0search0turn0search6

Web search results used (summary): - University of Twente news item describing launch and study of the Training in Positivity (TiP) app (TiP app description, goals, and study plan). citeturn0search0 - University of Twente student/pilot studies and theses evaluating the TiP app in students and specific groups (pilot effectiveness, user satisfaction). citeturn0search4turn0search3 - Related RCT literature on positive-psychology/gratitude apps during COVID‑19 showing digital positive-psychology interventions can improve well‑being in the general population. citeturn0search6turn0search7
